div.head: For the Spectator
div.summary: Letter complaining about Democratic behavior during and after the election.

div.excerpt: "Our neighbors know full well that the Southern gentlemen of whom the Opposition party is composed would never tolerate coalition with free negroes for the accomplishment of any political end."
div.summary: Spectator is responding to an article in the Vindicator that painted the opposition as a party of "Whigs, Americans Free Soilers, Free Niggers etc." The paper takes issue with the last category. It also discusses good Northern men who refuse to interfere with slavery in the South, even though they oppose it. Raises the specter of Black Republicanism.

div.head: Sad Occurrence

transcript.p: Mr. Wm. A. Perrin, of this place, was bitten by a rattle-snake at Stribling Springs, on Saturday afternoon last, and died from the effects of the poison on Sunday morning. He had caught the snake and was playing with it at the time the wound was inflicted.

div.summary: Perrin was bitten by a rattlesnake at Stribling Springs and died.

div.head: Dangers Ahead
div.summary: Announces increase in value of goods imported through the New York Customs House and expresses concern about a repeat of 1857 crisis.

div.head: Important Letter from Gov. Wise
div.origin: New York Herald; Philadelphia Press; Providence Journal; New York News; Journal of Commerce; New York Commercial Advertiser
div.summary: Reprint of a letter that Gov. Wise sent to the New York Democratic State Committee. He promises to defy Douglas and "crush" the Virginia Opposition. Wise calls for a united South and a united Virginia. Article includes other paper's commentaries. The letter is so outrageous that some call it a forgery.

div.head: Another Virginia Aspirant
div.summary: Article about 1860 Presidential election. Will Letcher run? What about Douglas? Or Yancey?

div.head: For the Spectator
div.summary: Response to Many Voters letter of August 2. Many Voters should not complain about the Council--they are elected and do a good job.

div.head: For the Spectator

transcript.p: Messrs. Editors.--I was at the Presbyterian Church on last Saturday, and was pleased to see it so neatly carpeted; but the question occurred to me, how can that neatness be preserved in a Church where so many tobacco chewers attend, and chew tobacco all the time? I wonder if gentlemen cannot be induced to forbear the use of the "weed" for about one hour and a half. I believe it is not considered genteel to chew tobacco in private parlors and spit over the carpets; if so, it must be looked upon as far from genteel to spit tobacco juice over the floor or carpet of the House of God.

div.summary: Wonders how the Presbyterian Church's new carpeting can be protected from tobacco chewers. Could they be asked to abstain while in church?
